div1.p: Carroll plans to write a magazine article on Walter Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Harry M. Carroll to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 1, 1926
div1.opener:
Harry M. Carroll
Lawyer
Donna, Texas June 1, 1926.
Mrs. Emilie L. Reed,
Blue Ridge Summit, Pa.
My dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
Stress of business has prevented my answering earlier your kind letter
of May 13th. Please accept my regrets for not having been in position to
write you before this.

Yes, I saw the article in the New York Times. It was very similar in
tone to one that was printed in the Gloucester Gazette, which was sent me
by the editor of that newspaper. We seem to be making progress towards the
realization of our desires, although I am not overly optimistic that what
action has so far been taken will get us any great distance ahead. I have
written Dr. Jones at Newport News asking what course his association intends
to pursue. When his reply reached me I will write you.

I am not surprised by what you tell me in your letter of the niggardli-
ness of Congress in the matter of your pension. Mr. Sullivan says in his
book that you have been allowed but $125 monthly, and that this pension did
not go into effect until 1923. I assume that Mr. Sullivan is correct. What
a contrast between Congress' generosity (1) to you and its generosity to it-
self when it voted a $2500 pay increase last year. I have been thinking
of doing a magazine article on the subject of Walter Reed and if I ever get
around to it I would like to mention this. Have you any objection?

I value your letters highly and hope that you will continue to write me
whenever the mood strikes you.
